elements.text: Written by Marjorie Blain Parker Illustrated by Sophie Burrows

This rhyming story follows a boy as he counts down to the start of kindergarten and dreams of things he looks forward to. By counting sleeps, he knows how many days until the big day! Will it ever get here?

Have children help you count to 10. Count up a few numbers at a time and pause, inviting children to say the next number in order. Repeat, counting backwards.
Have children count back from 10 as they sing “Ten Bottles of Milk.” They can act out taking one down and passing it around. Ask children to clap each time a number is said.

Multilingual learners may find counting backward difficult. Not only do they have to remember the names of the numbers in a new language, but they have to remember them in reverse order! Display a number line or the digits 0–10 in the classroom and refer to them to help children visualize which number comes before and after.
Share the Mind Builder: Manage Change

Change happens all the time. The weather changes from cloudy to sunny. We change our clothes to get ready for school. One big change was when you started coming to preschool! Sometimes, change can make us nervous. But change is a part of growing up for everyone. What do you think about the change from preschool to kindergarten? Let’s talk about it.

Change causes uncertainty in everyone, especially young children. Help children adapt to change this week by noticing the changes they make each day: moving from one play center to another; switching activities; and transitioning from classroom to home. Discuss the upcoming move to kindergarten, and encourage questions. (Read & Patterson, 1980)

At this stage, children are aware of past, present, and future. However, they are likely to have difficulty measuring time formally. Point to a clock or calendar to help children visualize the passage of time as you discuss hours and days. Will that happen in the future, or a time after now? We can use a calendar to measure how long that will be.

List careers children are interested in on a chart or board. Ask children to vote for one career to act out, and list the total votes for each career on the chart. Guide children to act out the winning career using any available props. Repeat with the next most popular careers.
Provide a writing prompt about what children want to be when they grow up. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

To find a successful career, you first need to know what you are good at and like doing. Talking with children about what they want to be when they grow up, even at this young age, helps them start to think about those questions. Ask children to share jobs that their family members have to help them brainstorm a list of potential careers.

Ask children to share their favorite games, songs, and activities from this year. Think of a few favorites beforehand in order to gather any props or materials needed.  Make a list of children’s choices on a chart or board. Read the options one by one, and have the class vote on which activity they want to do for this last Circle Time. Tally votes, and do the activities that get the most votes!
Play the PreK On My Way™ theme music one last time to celebrate the end of preschool. Invite children to dance and sing along however they wish!
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We learned about changes and what to expect in kindergarten. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
What will you do to get ready for kindergarten?
Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we’ll act out parts of the story!
Tom is going to wear new clothes to kindergarten! Do you think you will use anything new on the first day of kindergarten?
Let’s pretend to put new pencils in our bags for kindergarten!
Tom is also going to bring his toy and a snack to kindergarten with him. What do you want to bring to kindergarten from home?
Let’s pretend to put that special item from home into our bags.

Let’s all practice saying it together.

It’s the last day of preschool! Share with children how proud you are of them and how proud they should be of themselves. Ask children for any remaining questions they have about kindergarten, and share anything you know about the kindergarten classes they will join. If possible, schedule a visit before the end of the year.
